text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single horizontal rectangular miniature occupying the full width of the folio above a single-column text block; image separated from text by a narrow ruled line; generous upper margin framing the architectural canopy; visual hierarchy places the pictorial scene as the focal element before the reader encounters the text below.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textualis libraria with regular textura letterforms; professional book hand exhibiting uniform angular strokes, use of common medieval abbreviations (e.g., titulus bars, suspensions), and occasional decorative flourishes on ascenders and descenders.

color_scheme.color_usage: Monochrome pen-and-ink drawing without polychromy; all modeling achieved through linear hatching and contour line; no evidence of applied pigments or gold leaf in surviving state.

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen contours of uniform medium thickness; precise outlines with occasional variance to suggest weight and depth.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Parallel and cross hatching in folds of drapery; sparse short strokes to indicate volume on garments.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of figures by importance; minimal attempt at linear perspective; spatial depth implied only by overlapping hems and alternating ground-line breaks.

content_theme.scene_description: Under a gothic canopy, Christ stands at center with a nimbus, raising his right hand in blessing over a kneeling bishop-elect, whose mitre rests slightly back on his head and who holds a crozier vertically. Christ’s left hand gestures toward the candidate’s head in the ordination act. To Christ’s left (viewer’s right) sits a bishop on a low bench draped with cloth, leaning on his crozier and supporting his chin in contemplative repose; above this bishop floats an angelic figure with nimbus, offering an open book. To Christ’s right (viewer’s left), another bishop mirrors the seated posture, leaning on a table draped in cloth, mitre and cope in full view, crozier in hand. All figures wear flowing liturgical copes with delineated folds and pointed mitres with lappets. They are aligned on a single ground line beneath the pointed arch, with minimal background detail apart from the curtained recesses. The symmetrical arrangement and hierarchical sizes emphasize the central sacramental moment.

religious: Christ as ordaining figure with nimbus and blessing gesture
Seated bishop resting head on hand, holding crozier

objects: Draped cloths behind benches and tables
architectural: Pointed Gothic canopy with central finial

technical_features.material: Smooth, fine-caliber calfskin vellum prepared with a thin, even layer of chalk and glue; visible faint ruling in leadpoint for text and image alignment; typical folio of a 13th-century liturgical manuscript.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall very good: ink lines remain sharp with minimal fading; parchment shows light toning and minor foxing at margins; no recent pigment repairs, as original is monochrome; slight cockling at upper corner.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in leadpoint beneath ink contours
Absence of gesso layers for gilding
Uniform quill-pen strokes with no evidence of brushwork
Consistent ruling grid faintly visible under UV
No punchwork or tooling in margins

secondary_functions: Didactic illustration of the episcopal ordination rite
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical readership within a cathedral or monastic chapter, including bishops and their chaplains

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This monochrome miniature, likely produced in a northern French scriptorium during the late 13th century, reflects the liturgical and hierarchical preoccupations of the high medieval Church. Executed in a refined Gothic textualis style, the precise pen work and careful underdrawing point to a professional workshop environment, possibly connected to a cathedral chapter rather than a small monastic center. The architectural canopy and symmetrical arrangement of figures reveal the influence of contemporary Parisian manuscript illumination, where the emphasis on order and divine sanction reinforced ecclesiastical authority. Iconographically, Christ’s central position and the formal gesture of ordination underline the sacramental theology of apostolic succession, while the contemplative bishops to either side model the transmission of spiritual office. The presence of the angel offering the book may allude to the Book of the Gospels, emphasizing the word of God as the basis for episcopal teaching. Comparatively, this scene shares compositional parallels with ordination miniatures in the Reims and Chartres regions, yet its spare monochrome presentation suggests it may have served as a presentation drawing or as part of a liturgical manual rather than a fully polychrome pontifical. The work therefore occupies an intermediate position between preparatory cartoon and finished illumination, highlighting both traditional iconographic programs and the economy of monochrome drawing for instructional use.
